destination.label: Santiago
destination.title: A spellbinding destination of the southern hemisphere

content.intro:
Chile, a fantastic destination for history and nature buffs, is proud of its extremes and home to some of the most beautiful landscapes of the southern hemisphere.

Situated between Cape Horn, Easter Island, and Valparaiso, Chile is a land of contrasts and legends boasting a list of mythical places that haunt the dreams of every sailor in the world. Nature has been particularly conscientious in preserving this land, surrounded from north to south by desert or glaciers, quickened by the waves of the Pacific, and defended by soaring mountains, some of which reach 6,000 metres. Dominated by the equator, cold currents however temper the tropical influence. Consequently, there are a diversity of climates and inverted seasons, with summer looming in December and a shivering winter in June.
The adventure-loving traveller, those seeking solitude, or those enchanted by vertical cities, are sure to be dazzled and fascinated by the attractiveness of Chilean tourism, which will lead them from the foothills of the Andes to the Strait of Magellan, on paths still not frequented by crowds. Prepare to discover a spectacular and fantastic universe. Many snow-capped volcanoes and the purest air in the world define a dramatic landscape, while a supernatural maze of fjords, carved by the waves, border the salt seas and multi-coloured lagoons.
Santiago, the capital city, has had to bend to face the imperatives of urban sprawl, but it has managed to negotiate the face of modernity imposed by the end of the second millennium. With its colonial past and true to its Latin culture, its future coexists with the remains of New World civilisations and the fabulous treasures left behind by the conquistadors. Hospitable and festive, cultural and culinary, the leading city of Patagonia is full of museums and theatres, wineries and art galleries.
It is hard not to be captivated by the Chilean capital and its reserved, but ever so hospitable people, who remain a fine example of successful cross-cultural mixing, and who have given birth to ‘Chileanness' a deep sense of national identity that is unique on the continent.

content.title: Ambrosia, Chilean bistro with French inspirations

introduction.small: In the San Damian neighbourhood near the Cerro Alvarado Park, Santiago's green lung, this family restaurant offers a menu that blends French and Chilean gastronomies.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ambrosia, Chilean bistro with French inspirations

paragraphs.text:
The garden of this old townhouse opens onto a romantic patio, interspersed with a few colourful iron-wrought tables and chairs, perfect to sip on a drink. But truth be told, it is inside the house that everything happens. With stripped-down design and a cosy atmosphere, Ambrosia is a restaurant that looks like a French bistro with a Chilean twist. Regularly making the 50 best Latin American restaurants lists, the establishment is first and foremost a family affair: father and son on table service, the mother at the register and the daughter, Carolina Bazàn, in the kitchen. The chef trained with Gregory Marchand in Paris and kept a few French inspirations in her recipes, based on Chilean products – organic most of the time. The menu changes daily, depending on deliveries, but you may be lucky enough to try venison with mushroom purée, the conger and mash cauliflower in ink, or the fillet of duck breast with a quince purée. There is something for everyone!

Ambrosia
Pamplona 78
Santiago
Vitacura

www.ambrosia.cl ﻿

Menu: around 29,000 CLP

content.title: Tapas, pisco sours and Chilean wines at Casaluz

introduction.small: In the heart of the lively Barrio Italiano, this restaurant-bar pays tribute to national wines, along with Mediterranean-inspired tapas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tapas, pisco sours and Chilean wines at Casaluz

paragraphs.text:
The black and white checked pattern tiles give a vintage feel to Casaluz's patio, lit up with colourful candle holders. Hidden in the back of the dining room, between large rustic-looking walls covered with luxurious plants, this secret garden delights regulars at any time of day or night with its intimate and enchanting atmosphere. Some nights, it even turns into a music venue, which only adds to the magic.
At the bar, mixologists work hard to prepare subtle cocktails, from classic mojito to Chilean pisco sour – pisco, local eau-de-vie and lemon juice. Wine lovers will also find something to their taste, with various tributes to the country's small producers. Choose among a large selection (Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Merlot, Pinot Noir, Chardonnay…) and discover what makes Chili such a renowned wine maker. Wearing two hats as both bar and restaurant, Casaluz offers typically Spanish tapas – patatas bravas, boquerones en escabeche… - best paired with the tasting. Ask for some advice and enjoy the perfect combo!

content.title: Los Dominicos, craftsmanship in all its forms

introduction.small: Proud of its arts and crafts, the Los Dominicos Village is the perfect place to find a souvenir of your Chilean journey to bring back home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Los Dominicos, craftsmanship in all its forms

paragraphs.text:
With an area of 27,000 sqm, Los Dominicos is the largest craft centre in the country. If you have the opportunity during your holiday, take a detour through this charming village to find the rare gem. Here is a concentration of at least 160 workshops all selling the highest quality items, handmade by couturiers, sculptors, painters, ceramists, cabinetmakers… You will simply be carried away by the many wonders.
For over 30 years, artisans from the region have set up shop near the Church of San Vicente Ferrer – an elegant monument with its two green copper cupolas – to attract tourists and showcase their craft.
However, do not expect only craftsmanship in Los Dominicos. Houses are built in adobe, a clay mixed with water and straw, which gives the village typical fascinating character. Besides visiting the shops, you will also have the opportunity to attend concerts and plays, take a walk in the botanical garden and enjoy many traditional dishes.

content.title: Santa Lucía Hill, a cultural icon

introduction.small: Not far from the Centro de Exposición de Arte Indígena is Santa Lucía, a charming park that offers a spectacular view of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Santa Lucía Hill, a cultural icon

paragraphs.text:
Right in the heart of the city centre, from 629 metres up, Santa Lucía Hill's park offers the most splendid of views of the historic district of Santiago. It can be accessed by Alameda Bernardo O'Higgins, the capital's main street, which will allow you to make a stop at the Centro de Exposición de Arte Indígena. Established in 1996 to recognize and honour ethnic and cultural differences, the museum enables you to discover three populations present on the territory of Chile since the pre-Columbian period, by means of their crafts: the Aymara, Rapa Nui and Mapuche.
After your visit, head to the public park and take the double staircase, built by Chilean architect Victor Henri Villeneuve, which is a remarkable work of art. You will also come across La Terrasse de Neptune, a creation of the French artist Mathurin Moreau, and pass under the most majestic triumphal arch. The main attraction of this park is undoubtedly Castillo Hidalgo, built during the colonial era, which you will be able to explore leisurely. Santa Lucía Hill ensures a pleasant walk between gardens and fountains, far from the bustle of the capital.

Centro de Exposición de Arte Indígena
Cerro Santa Lucía
Alameda Bernardo O'Higgins 499
Santiago 8320000

Santa Lucía Hill

content.title: La Chascona: the house-museum of the poet Pablo Neruda

introduction.small: Though there are two other Pablo Neruda houses in Chile, La Chascona reveals the intimacy of the artist, as this is where he lived with his third wife, Matilde Urrutia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Chascona: the house-museum of the poet Pablo Neruda

paragraphs.text:
Set on a hill in Bellavista, this is where the whimsical Chilean poet lived until his last days, preserving the memory of an original and creative life. A house museum, it is now the headquarters of the Pablo Neruda Foundation, and part of the National Heritage since 1990.

Arranged like a boat, it contains a round part that evokes a lighthouse and extends to lush exotic gardens, cherished by his muse. A compulsive collector and prolific writer, acknowledged with a Nobel Prize for Literature in 1971, Neruda enjoyed this decor of miscellaneous objects, loaded with paintings, books and manuscripts collected during trips, or collected from artist friends.

Just next to the property is a cultural space that has been opened for readings and book presentations. It is intended to accommodate various events on the subject of poetry and to exhibit personal items of Neruda's that are still unknown to the public.

La Chascona

content.title: Santiago Museum of Contemporary Art: high profile exhibitions

introduction.small: Attached to the Museum of Fine Arts, the MAC is located in a masterpiece of neoclassical architecture, topped by a monumental glass dome.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Santiago Museum of Contemporary Art: high profile exhibitions

paragraphs.text:
This museum showcases artists from Chile and around the world from the 19th century to today. The main collections house almost 2,600 works of art, including sculptures, drawings, prints, ceramics, and more than 600 paintings. Most of the works were bequeathed to the museum by Chilean artists and foreign artists with an address in Chile.

The MAC makes it possible to explore the pictorial universe of Latin American painters such as Roberto Matta and Pablo Burchard, Emilio Pettoruti, Alejandro Obregón, and Fernando Szyszlo. The eclectic collection of bronze and stone sculptures is very moving, and its centrepiece, a bronze signed by Isamu Noguchi, a Japanese-American sculptor, is very highly acclaimed.

A must-see before leaving is the international collection of lithographs, sketches, and engravings, among which are works by Friedensreich Hundertwasser, the renowned Austrian author, painter, and engraver.

Santiago Museum of Contemporary Art
Ismael Valdés Vergara
Santiago
RegiónMetropolitana

www.mac.uchile.cl

content.title: San Cristóbal: a delightful walk on the heights of Santiago

introduction.small: The bravest can ignore the cable car to Pio Nono street and climb the 860-metrehill, which offers a unique and spectacular view of the Chilean capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: San Cristóbal: a delightful walk on the heights of Santiago

paragraphs.text:
Chileans have turned this nugget of the Bellavista neighbourhood into a veritable cult. Pope John Paul II celebrated Mass here in 1987 and at the top, a monumental statue of the Virgin of the Immaculate Conception embraces the horizon with a majesty that evokes the Corcovado in Rio de Janeiro.

From here, the city gracefully yields its landmarks, surrounded by the snowy mountain ranges of the Andes and the Costa. With their thousands of annual visitors, several snack bars and a handful of souvenir shops encourage shopping while offering refreshments. Halfway up is the Chilean National Zoo, famous for the quality of its facilities and its very protective philosophy towards native species of the continent.

Here you will meet the Magellan fox, the condor, the pudú, and the flamingo. There are also penguins, for which the natural environment has been restored in part.

Cerro San Cristóbal
Santiago

content.title: Colchagua Valley: a stop on the wine road

introduction.small: The valleys of Aconcagua, Casablanca, San Antonio-Leyda, Maipo, Cachapoal, Curicó, and Maule join that of Colchagua to offer an exciting vineyard tour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Colchagua Valley: a stop on the wine road

paragraphs.text:
The Colchagua Valley, around the sleepy town of Santa Cruz, alone produces 13 of the most prestigious wines of Chile. Its bucolic route winds through the Chilean countryside and vineyards, where the Jesuits planted the first vines in the 16th century.

Among the domains and bodegas open to the public, you have the choice between ViuManent, Las Niñas, Casa Lapostolle, Casa Silva, and others. The tastings feature the famous full-bodied red Chilean wines made primarily with Cabernet Sauvignon, Carmenère, and Syrah. In the tasting room, your guide will reveal the specifics of Chilean production that enabled the Colchagua Valley to be ranked as the best wine region in the world in 2005.

On the way back, the Colchagua Museum is worth a detour for its treasures of pre-Columbian ceramics and antique winemaking tools.

Province de Colchagua
Région du Libertador General Bernardo O'Higgins

content.title: El Huerto: a top the vegetarian trend

introduction.small: This adept of 100% vegetarian has been centre stage for 30 years; it also organises painting exhibitions and yoga classes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Huerto: a top the vegetarian trend

paragraphs.text:
Though the garden terrace is quite charming, the rustic atmosphere is a bit homely, which has not prevented El Huerto from being considered as one of the 25 best vegetarian restaurants in the world.

Ahead of the trends, the house philosophy is respected without flaw, allowing you to combine gastronomy and selective food for health without worry. Very attractive, colourful, and rich in flavours, the recipes are international and inspired by world cuisine. The journey can begin with Tuscany and an ingratiating lasagne, Lebanese tabbouleh, or Mexican quesadillas. Try the different kinds of tofu, seaweed, peppers, and herbs that make surprising alliances. Creative mixtures give prestige to an omelette with mushrooms in very good French style, and the Thai wok is customised, and sprinkled with coriander.

The menu features a generous and varied selection of salads, as well as fresh fruit cocktails, that are vibrantly delicious.

El Huerto

content.title: Atacama: chic version of a desert

introduction.small: Guarded by the Andes, the Atacama conceals heady charms. In a lunar landscape, volcanoes, snowy peaks, and dunes coexist in a remarkably clear sky.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Atacama: chic version of a desert

paragraphs.text:
This normally hostile natural world is wrapped in a veil of poetry of unreal beauty, dotted with the urbanised landmarks of Copiapó, Antofagasta, Iquique, and Arica.

It is no coincidence that San Pedro de Atacama stands out as the first destination in northern Chile. There are sumptuous lodges offering explorations of the region in conditions of optimal comfort in this luxuriant oasis. In recent years, restaurants, bars, and trekking agencies have popped up in the villages, which still have all their appeal.

A thousand and one wonders of nature mark your route to the west. The mysterious Valle de la Luna (Valley of the Moon) and its shifting dunes carved by the wind, the Salar de Uyuni, the largest salt desert in the world, colonised by pink flamingos, and also the incredible Pica, celebrated for its lemon groves and mango trees, are all sublime.

Atacama Desert,
Antofagasta,
Antofagasta Region

content.title: Enjoy Viña del Mar: a four-star hotel with its feet in the water

introduction.small: With its beautiful white sand beaches and its multitude of luxury hotels, restaurants, and clubs, Valparaiso's festive Viña del Mar district is playing in the majors.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy Viña del Mar: a four-star hotel with its feet in the water

paragraphs.text:
Among the best places on the Chilean Riviera, this hotel offers direct beach access and is dedicated to relaxation and leisure. It has a huge casino, where more than a hundred slot machines and game tables attract thrill seekers. The establishment is renowned for its modern, very spacious rooms and large balconies that open on to the sea or the valley.

There are two restaurants, one serving brasserie style dishes and another with a more sophisticated menu, with the great standards of international gastronomy. The fitness area offers Ayurvedic treatments, a sauna, a tennis court, and a swimming pool for recharging your batteries before dancing through the night on the OVO dance floor.

People come from all over Chile to this vibrant disco, animated by a resident DJ and also host to international scale concerts.

content.title: Chilean Museum of Pre-Columbian Art: a priceless heritage

introduction.small: Its neoclassical facade is home to rare collections that are witness to the rich diversity of Latin American peoples

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chilean Museum of Pre-Columbian Art: a priceless heritage

paragraphs.text:
This museum, one of the most important in Santiago, owes its existence to the initiative of architect Sergio Larraín García-Moreno, an amateur art connoisseur who is also passionate about Latin America. More than 50 civilisations are represented, with collections that attest to the important cultural heritage of these pre-16th-century populations, including statues, textiles, ceramics, and gold objects. The visit is organised around vast designated areas where the recurring themes of the pre-Columbian cycle, notably sacrifices, shamanism, music, and dance, are concentrated. The works of the permanent exhibits are grouped by regions, and there is a room dedicated to the native peoples of Chile. An exciting rendezvous with the history, traditions, and rituals of the Mayan Empire, Aztec, Inca, Aymara and Mapuche peoples, and the Patagonian giants, the Tehuelches. Every year, the museum organises temporary exhibitions around themes on pre-Columbian peoples, such as the recent ‘Chile under the Inca Empire'.

Chilean Museum of Pre-Columbian Art
Bandera 361
Santiago

+56 (2) 2697 1500

www.precolombino.cl

content.title: The Aubrey Boutique Hotel: a night in a mansion

introduction.small: A leading boutique hotel, this urban sanctuary has taken possession of an English manor house, built in the 1920s for a wealthy railway tycoon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Aubrey Boutique Hotel: a night in a mansion

paragraphs.text:
In the district of Bellavista, the cultural heart of the Santiago, this residence has preserved the identity of its colourful colonial past. The medieval stone facade maintains its allure, as a backdrop to the fountains and patios, fragrant flowers and exotic plants. The 15 rooms and suites open onto the lush vegetation of the Cerro San Cristóbal, in a comfortable atmosphere propitious for art, space, and modernity. The atmosphere remains very convivial in the lounge bar with tastings of cocktails from around the world. The dining room of Pasta E Vino has a history. For three decades, legendary breakfasts were held here, attended by the leading social and political elite, including President Alessandri, in office until 1938. Today, the menu has turned to fine Italian cuisine. On the menu, fresh duck ravioli, gnocchi and spinach ricotta, risotto, seafood appetisers and salads, always accompanied by the best Chilean wines.

content.title: The Castillo Rojo: a small, red 1920s Baroque castle

introduction.small: Discover one of the emblematic places of Santiago in a lively area of bars, concert venues, and theatres.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Castillo Rojo: a small, red 1920s Baroque castle

paragraphs.text:
On the whim of a Russian billionaire, the ‘castle' was once the fount of a bohemian community, frequented by artists and philosophers.

In 2013, two renowned young Chilean architects completely redesigned the spaces. An alliance of modernity and elegance has restored all the brilliance to this aristocratic setting, which has preserved its identity and historical references. In a chic vintage atmosphere, furniture, mouldings, and original fireplaces contribute to the authenticity of the 19 rooms. All are different and all offer spectacular views of the snow-capped Andes or the Plaza Mori. The top floor houses a bright suite with a nice sitting area and a private roof terrace, while the gardens offer a green parenthesis between buildings.

For dining at the hotel, the Cabildo with its Chilean menu, or the Pétanque, a French brasserie, are both excellent choices.

content.title: Singular Santiago: a favourite in the Barrio Lastarria

introduction.small: Designed in the same spirit as its predecessor, the Singular Patagonia Puerto Natale, the newest luxury hotel in Santiago is a showcase of excellence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Singular Santiago: a favourite in the Barrio Lastarria

paragraphs.text:
The Singular is a driver in the rise of this charming quarter, and a refuge for a number of artists and creators. The 62 rooms and suites of this five-star hotel display a bias for pure luxury.

To forget the frenzy of the city, a delightful wellness getaway is organised around the pool before entering the spa, with a hammam and sauna. Musicians play in the lobby some week nights as well as at the lively rooftop cocktail bar. The hotel lives up to its reputation, focused on the outstanding quality of its services and hospitality. When dining on the patio, guests can choose from an international menu concocted by Laurent Pasqualetto, a former chef at Fouquet's in Paris.

The street the hotel is on is full of shops and friendly bars, and also has a popular neighbourhood market with colourful stands representing the diversity and creativity of local crafts.

content.title: Barrio Italia: the antiques district

introduction.small: All around the Avenida Italia, between Providencia and Nunoa, the Barrio Italia, has been booming since the early 20th century, without forgetting its colonial past and historical wonders.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Barrio Italia: the antiques district

paragraphs.text:
This feverish quarter is a paradise for antiques and design enthusiasts. With its trendy bars and fashionable restaurants, the place has no shortage of character. The fiefdom for decorators and antique dealers has also opened up to fashion designers and artists, in a unifying and creative dynamic.

Barrio Italia awakens from around 12:30 p.m.and its party atmosphere evokes both the eclectic concept of the Parisian Flea Market of Saint-Ouen and the bobo-chic Ibiza markets. Here and there, art galleries, unusual shops, clothes and jewellery retailers feature the avant-garde productions of Chilean artists.

At the heart of the trend, stands with furniture and vintage objects continue to multiply. Take a stroll under the arcades of the Estación Italia, where there are rare vinyl recordings, ceramic eggs and late 18th-century chandeliers.

Barrio Italia

content.title: Restobar KY: a confidential address

introduction.small: No sign, no lights… a great evening awaits you in this secret address, hidden behind a screen of graffiti.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Restobar KY: a confidential address

paragraphs.text:
The staging is worthy of a detective film. Even taxis have difficulty finding this anonymous address. You have to ring the bell to be let in…

After a moment of stupor, you enter a delicious lounge-inspired cocoon. The unique decor with touches of ‘recycled kitsch' includes high-backed, plush padded benches of all colours, lattice walls, wood panelling, and plants galore. But above all, remember that this place, frequented by a young and trendy cosmopolitan clientele, is both an excellent Thai restaurant and also a fantastic bar. Before dinner, browse the wine and international cocktails lists, and let yourself be tempted by one of the bartender's original proposals.

In the kitchens you will be offered the best of Thai cuisine exotic, spicy, or delicate,as you wish but that is not the only speciality of the house, as the menu also suggests a surprising camembert pesto…

content.title: Bellavista: bohemian Santiago

introduction.small: With its walls adorned with graffiti, artist houses,and a vibrant nightlife, this very green area is one of Santiago's main attractions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bellavista: bohemian Santiago

paragraphs.text:
Bellavista incarnates Santiago's bohemian soul with its original architecture, street art, and distinctive cityscapes. History, leisure, and shopping are inseparable, along picturesque streets that may be explored on foot or by funicular.

Everywhere, there are astonishing art galleries and boutiques, tucked into improbable sheds or doorways. The atmosphere on Calle PíoNono is cheerful. The cafés monopolise terraces and sidewalks, where people dance to the sound of orchestras. Stroll to the Feria Artesanal, which deserves a look for its authentic spirit, then browse the Patio Bellavista, a modern shopping complex.

Here there are more bars, wine shops, and souvenir stores. Gems and jewellery are focused on Avenida Bellavista. Sellers there are specialised in the sale of objects and jewellery made of lapis lazuli, a beautiful gemstone that is widespread in northern Chile.

content.title: Araucano Park: a pleasant interlude of sun and nature.

introduction.small: Santiago's green lung is in the Las Condes area, a vast woodland that is a delicious promise of serenity and fresh air for city dwellers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Araucano Park: a pleasant interlude of sun and nature.

paragraphs.text:
Surrounded by a vertical cityscape and busy avenues, the park stretches over 22 hectares of lawns and gardens. Criss-crossed by a maze of marked trails and bike paths, it is a delight for walkers and sportsmen. Araucano Park has evolved over the years to include an ultra-modern leisure complex.

Besides the famous Kidzania,dedicated to children, it is equipped with playgrounds and picnic areas, not to mention the public swimming pool, which is indispensable for cooling off on sunny days. It is a very busy place and can also claim status as a national cultural centre, evidenced by the many popular concerts, exhibitions, and quality events that take place during the year.

You can also attend theatre and film festivals, as well as international chess tournaments. At the edge of the park there are bars and restaurants for friendly, robust dining.

Parque Araucano
Las Condes
Santiago
Región Metropolitana

content.title: Hotel Casa Galos: an intimate and warm address

introduction.small: A port city and a legendary landfall with a colonial past, Valparaiso retains its title of Queen of the Costa Santiago.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Casa Galos: an intimate and warm address

paragraphs.text:
Perched on a hillside, with its ancient labyrinth of alleys, its elevators and graffiti, the city of Pablo Neruda has an atmosphere all its own.

At the Casa Galos,housed in a 19th century building where the welcome is warm and given in all languages,you will feel at home, away from home. In 2012, the venue enjoyed a careful restoration of its spaces and decor. Nine beautiful rooms, some with a mezzanine, and six ultra-functional apartments in an ethno-chic style, offer spectacular views of the hills of Valparaiso.

With the exciting walking tour offered by the owner, you can discover the essence of this colonial city and the history, secrets, and architecture of this changing neighbourhood, which in the past, was a favourite resort of English immigrants.

content.title: Metropolitan Cathedral of Santiago: a major religious building

introduction.small: It is difficult to ignore the massive architecture of this building overlooking the Plaza de Armas, especially as it symbolises the favourite place of Catholic worship for Chileans.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Metropolitan Cathedral of Santiago: a major religious building

paragraphs.text:
The cathedral is a contemporary of the city, founded in 1541. By the will of Don Pedro de Valdivia, the lieutenant of the conquistador Pizarro, Santiago was built as a garrison town with long streets at right angles that converge on a central armoury.

The highlight, the original cathedral, a victim of the powerful earthquakes that have shaken the continent over the past 300 years, has been rebuilt five times. The current facade was built under the direction of an Italian architect, before its consecration in 1840. This monumental stone vessel, influenced by neoclassicism, represents the central axis of an episcopal city that includes the Archbishopric and the Church of Sagrario.

Though the arcades lined with pink marble supporting its vault are spectacular, it is also interesting to see the paintings in the nave for the intensity of their religious scenes. A crypt under the main altar houses the tombs of prelates who have shaped the history of the city.

Catedral Metropolitana
Plaza de Armas
Santiago
Región Metropolitana

+56 (2) 2787 5600

www.iglesiadesantiago.cl

content.title: Peumayen: an unusual experience

introduction.small: Acclaimed by the international press for the originality of its cuisine, the Peumayen invites you to try the traditions of the indigenous peoples of Chile.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Peumayen: an unusual experience

paragraphs.text:
The setting is contemporary and ultra-chic, extended by a pleasant patio highlighted by natural elements of wood, cane, and stone.

The menu takes you into unknown territories, so the attentive presence of the waiter is required to order. Resolutely innovative, the taste experience is highly original. Lose yourself in this gourmet journey, which borrows codes from ancestral gastronomy. Reinterpreted with modernity, this cuisine with vegetarian leanings selects the best products and the expertise of pre-Hispanic peoples such as the Chilote, Rapanui, Aymara, and Mapuche. For the appetiser, a tasting plate is the best choice for an overview of the house philosophy.

Presented with exquisite taste, river fish, entirely unknown vegetables,and exotic meats are major chords of a symphony of flavours, with herbs and spices offering fascinating subtleties for the taste buds.

Peumayen Ancestral Food

content.title: Opera Catedral: a festive atmosphere in a designer setting

introduction.small: Renowned for the consistency of its cuisine, this restaurant is an institution for business lunches, or dinners with friends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Opera Catedral: a festive atmosphere in a designer setting

paragraphs.text:
You can have lunch or dinner on the terrace of this designer brasserie, but the regulars prefer the first floor. The menu, written in French, offers typical French specialties that have been slightly revisited. Sole is “meunière”-style and the salmon is cooked in brown butter, capers, parsley and lemon juice. Other dishes are equally as satisfying, like the fillet of beef and the seafood risotto. Impressive for the complexity of its choice, the restaurant's wine cellar holds its own, navigating between grands crus and small labels with promising futures, about which the sommelier is happy to advise. On the second floor, the atmosphere is very relaxed with a live music programme of small, easy listening concerts during dinner.

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Santiago
content.introduction: Santiago enjoys a typically Mediterranean climate. Winters (from June to September) are relatively mild, occasionally visited by violent rainstorms. Summers (from December to March) tend to be hot and dry.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Chile is the Chilean Peso (CLP).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Arturo-Merino-Benítez International Airport
airports.description:
The Arturo-Merino-Benítez International Airport is located about 17 kilometres (11 miles) northwest of the city centre, in Pudahuel.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Santiago and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via Ruta 68 and the Alameda.
    • Short-term parking lot (about CLP 1,205 per half hour) and long-term parking lot (CLP 24,100 per day) available at the airport.
    • Several car rental companies have counters on the first floor of the arrivals halls, next to baggage claim.
  • By bus
    • Several private companies offer bus services connecting the airport with the city's residential districts and its historic centre. The trip takes about 45 minutes and fares are about CLP 1,800 each way.
  • By taxi
    • Official taxis are located at the ranks just outside the airport. The trip to central Santiago costs around CLP 11,000.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +56 2 2690 1796
  • Website: https://www.nuevopudahuel.cl/?language=en

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Santiago
transportation.description: Santiago is a very large city and distances between points of interest are considerable. However, the city has a well-developed, efficient and reliable public transport system. You will never have any difficulty getting around.

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is recommended that you obtain insurance covering health care expenses as well as medical evacuation or repatriation before you leave home. Santiago counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to Chile.
However, the following vaccines are recommended:

  • booster doses for protection against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and polio
  • typhoid, hepatitis A and B
  • For longer stays, it is recommended to get vaccinated against rabies.

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Spanish phrases that will make your stay in Santiago a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: ¡ Buenos días ! (morning) / ¡ Buenas tardes ! (afternoon)
What time is it ?: ¿ Que hora es ?

Sorry: Disculpe (to say sorry)
Excuse me: Con permiso (to get past) / ¡ Por favor ! (to get attention).
How much is (…)?: ¿ Cuál es el precio de (…) ? /¿ Cuánto es ?
Where can I find (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo encontrar (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo comprar (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Santiago
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Santiago each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March/April: Easter Monday (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The Resurrection of Christ gives rise to many processions, and baptisms are celebrated on Easter Weekend, the most important moment of the Christian calendar.

events.title: September 18: Independence Day and Armed Forces Day (Fiestas Patrias, national holiday)
events.description: Commemoration of the Independence of Chile in 1810, with military parades followed by a huaso rodeo, a Chilean manifestation during which two horsemen compete to catch a young calf.

events.title: October 12: Día de la Raza (national holiday)
events.description: In recent years, this day has evolved into a celebration of the cultural richness engendered by the mixing of peoples. Parades are held through the streets, as well as singing and dancing.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Chile
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be visiting Chile for less than three months. However, your passport must be valid for at least six months from your date of entry.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Santiago and Chile, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Chile page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs' website: view information for travellers to Chile

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Santiago, it is customary to leave a 10% tip in restaurants, unless a service charge is included in the bill. Although US dollars are commonly seen in Chile, it is preferable to offer the tip in Chilean pesos.
